Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content:
"PirlGuard System
With the PirlGuard Protocol deployed the chances of an attack succeeding are vastly reduced. As we know once the attacker has created a longer chain through privately mining a separate chain they will then have to broadcast it to the network. Once the attacker opens their node for peering it will attempt to peer with rest of the nodes on the network, telling them that they are wrong. However, once this happens PirlGuard will drop the peer and penalize them by sentencing them to mine X amount of penalty blocks due to their un-peered mining. The amount of penalty blocks assigned depends on the amount of blocks that the malicious miner mined in private."  Couldnt you just have peers on the private chain network, circumventing all of this?   Or even more maliciously,  have pirlguard block out legitimate miners as they wouldnt have been peers in the attackers version of pirl

Content: LOKI coin is doing some kind of 51% protection, I skimmed this but I actually can't understand 90% of it, maybe because of XMR/CN jargon: https://github.com/loki-project/loki-improvement-protocols/blob/master/LIPS/LIP-3.md

Content: they involve masternodes, since that coin seems to be mostly "XMR + masternodes"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `Any block deeper than 12 blocks in the chain that has more than three checkpoints should then be considered final and cannot be reorganised.`

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: KMD DPoW seems better, but what do I know

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Depenends ... dPoW requires the TX to be confirmed before the checkpoint is active ... so miners can refuse to mine notarisation txs as genie pointed out this morning ... but however making all miners do this seems difficult.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: pirlguard would seem to have a hard time achieving consensus when the network splits. how can they assure the exact same penalty is given for offchain violations of mining too fast? it seems if the attacker released a different amount of blocks to different peers, wouldn they all end up requiring different amount of penalty? and wouldnt that permanently fork the chain?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: be carefuly when you roll your own encryption or security protocol. it is a lot harder than it sounds and takes years of field testing to get it working properly.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dPoW isnt perfect, but it is practical and field tested

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
the loki has some good points that BCH ABC should pay attention to:
The other, more naive approach is to simply cap reorganisations greater than P blocks. However there are serious problems with this approach, if an attacker can produce a chain of length P+1 and submit it to a different edge of the network as the non attacking chain is being checkpointed, then the network will diverge and will be unable to merge back into a single chain, effectively permanently forking the chain. This attack could, for example, deliberately target an exchange to put the exchange on a fork controlled by the attacker but distinct from the main network until manual maintenance is undertaken by the exchange to re-sync to the proper network chain. 
###

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I believe ZEN also adopted something based on reorg limits, though a pretty large amount.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: loki has masternodes, which they use to create something similar to single chain notarization, but not to any higher hashrate chain. so, not bad but the masternodes are then open to being attacked without having a reference from a higher hashrate chain
